lexUnit.name: lodge.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: stay at someone else's home.

sentence.text: Privately Emily thought Mr Frogmore could n't be of great means if he was lodging at Mrs Marsh 's house in Oystermouth .

When the Archimandrite suggested that the two ladies might like to lodge at the monastery that night , she was briefly dismissive ; when he pressed his offer of hospitality further , she was brusque .
He says the king ` lodged at a gentleman 's house in Stamford whose name the examinant knows not " .
Tonight we are to lodge at the Blue Boar inn near High Cross , the same tavern the Usurper rested at before Bosworth .
They could lodge with Grandpa during the week and go home at week-ends .
Two of his fellow ministers , Mr. Thomas Baldwin and Mr. Joseph Read lodged with him .
Danny , his wife and two kids were forced to lodge with friends while they searched for new digs .
At the time she was lodging with two ladies who had lost their brother in the First World War .
Back once more , Vincent moved to another village , Cuesmes , where he lodged in a house divided in two .
The downward spiral in their relationship was observed by the poet Alan Ross , who lodged in the boiler room at 37 Hamilton Terrace for the better part of a year .
However , we do know that whilst Margaret was lodging in Aldersgate , Richard was staying not very far away , with a friend , in Little Britain .
She could n't understand why I needed to lodge in London at all , but insisted that any accommodation I settled on had to be approved by the university authorities .
It struck me that this place must be fairly normal as lodging houses go , for on the whole the lodgers did not complain .
Ixora remained silent as they drove back to the lodging house in Castries .
` He will lodge tonight at Ely Palace , maman , " the prince told her .
